template.template: Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3
template.name: Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3
template.description:
Zabbix template for Microsoft SQL Server.
Tested on Microsoft SQL Server 2012, 2014, 2016 and 2019. It may work with earlier versions, but some items (with missing performance counters) may be unsupported. Tested on Zabbix 3.4.0. and 4.0.0. It may work with earlier versions, but some items (for example service.info[service,<param>]) may be unsupported.
For Low Level Discovery to work additional scripts must be configured.
Mantas Tumenas. mantas.tumenas@gmail.com

discovery_rule.name: SQL Server Instances Discovery
discovery_rule.description: SQL Server instances discovery with additional scripts lets discover Microsoft SQL Server instances.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Long running SQL Agent job
item_prototype.description: SQL Agent job has been running for more than 360 minutes.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Not synchronized logins or jobs
item_prototype.description: Availability Groups replicas on server {#SQLINSTANCENAME} have not synchronized SQL server logins or SQL Agent jobs.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Database Engine Critical Errors
item_prototype.description:
Microsoft SQL Server critical errors from Microsoft Windows Event Viewer.
Application (program) events. The Application log contains events logged by applications or programs. Events are classified as error, warning, or information, depending on the severity of the event. An error is a significant problem, such as loss of data. A warning is an event that isn't necessarily significant, but might indicate a possible future problem. An information event describes the successful operation of a program, driver, or service.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Could not allocate a new page
item_prototype.description: Msg 1101 or 1105 was logged in the Windows Application Event Log. These errors indicate that SQL server could not allocate a new page for database because of insufficient disk space in filegroup. Create the necessary space by dropping objects in the filegroup, adding additional files to the filegroup, or setting Autogrowth on for existing files in the filegroup.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Transaction log for database is full
item_prototype.description: The transaction log for database is full. To find out why space in the log cannot be reused, see the log_reuse_wait_desc column in sys.databases.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Database Integrity Errors Part 1
item_prototype.description:
Microsoft SQL Server database integrity errors from Microsoft Windows Event Viewer.
Application (program) events. The Application log contains events logged by applications or programs. Events are classified as error, warning, or information, depending on the severity of the event. An error is a significant problem, such as loss of data. A warning is an event that isn't necessarily significant, but might indicate a possible future problem. An information event describes the successful operation of a program, driver, or service.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Database Integrity Errors Part 2
item_prototype.description:
Microsoft SQL Server database integrity errors from Microsoft Windows Event Viewer.
Application (program) events. The Application log contains events logged by applications or programs. Events are classified as error, warning, or information, depending on the severity of the event. An error is a significant problem, such as loss of data. A warning is an event that isn't necessarily significant, but might indicate a possible future problem. An information event describes the successful operation of a program, driver, or service.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Database Backup Errors
item_prototype.description:
Microsoft SQL Server backup errors from Microsoft Windows Event Viewer.
Event IDs are selected and reviewed from sys.messages table.
SELECT * FROM sys.messages WHERE [text] LIKE '%backup%' AND language_id = 1033 AND is_event_logged = 1 AND severity <> 10 ORDER BY message_id ASC
Application (program) events. The Application log contains events logged by applications or programs. Events are classified as error, warning, or information, depending on the severity of the event. An error is a significant problem, such as loss of data. A warning is an event that isn't necessarily significant, but might indicate a possible future problem. An information event describes the successful operation of a program, driver, or service.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: SQL Server hang condition
item_prototype.description: Msg 17883, 17884, 17887, or 17888 was logged in the Windows Application Event Log. These errors indicate that a hang condition was detected by SQL Server. This condition can result in application problems such as login timeouts, query timeouts, or execution failures. In some cases, this condition is isolated to a set of users based on a scheduler. In other cases the entire SQL Server might be affected. This error condition can often be the cause of a cluster failover.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Server: Service State

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,,"Information|Warning|Error|Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",^(1101|1105)$,,skip].logeventid(1101|1105)}=1
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,,"Information|Warning|Error|Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",^(1101|1105)$,,skip].nodata({$EVENTLOGTIME})}=1 or {TRIGGER.VALUE}=0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Could not allocate a new page
trigger_prototype.description: Msg 1101 or 1105 was logged in the Windows Application Event Log. These errors indicate that SQL server could not allocate a new page for database because of insufficient disk space in filegroup. Create the necessary space by dropping objects in the filegroup, adding additional files to the filegroup, or setting Autogrowth on for existing files in the filegroup.

trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,,"Warning|Error|Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",^(2516|2517|3041|3134|3266|3313|3314|3315|3316|3417|3431|3443|3456|5173|5176|9004|14420|17208|17557|18204|18210|18273|35268|35269)$,,skip].nodata({$EVENTLOGTIME})}=1 or {TRIGGER.VALUE}=0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Database Backup Errors
trigger_prototype.description:
INCIDENT REQUIRES MANUAL CLOSURE in the ZABBIX Microsoft SQL Server backup errors from Microsoft Windows Event Viewer.
Event IDs are selected and reviewed from sys.messages table.
SELECT * FROM sys.messages WHERE [text] LIKE '%backup%' AND language_id = 1033 AND is_event_logged = 1 AND severity <> 10 ORDER BY message_id ASC
Application (program) events. The Application log contains events logged by applications or programs. Events are classified as error, warning, or information, depending on the severity of the event. An error is a significant problem, such as loss of data. A warning is an event that isn't necessarily significant, but might indicate a possible future problem. An information event describes the successful operation of a program, driver, or service.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,,"Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",,,skip].strlen()}>0 and {TRIGGER.VALUE}=0
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,,"Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",,,skip].nodata({$EVENTLOGTIME})}=1 and {TRIGGER.VALUE}=0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Database Engine Critical Errors
trigger_prototype.description:
Microsoft SQL Server critical errors from Microsoft Windows Event Viewer.
Application (program) events. The Application log contains events logged by applications or programs. Events are classified as error, warning, or information, depending on the severity of the event. An error is a significant problem, such as loss of data. A warning is an event that isn't necessarily significant, but might indicate a possible future problem. An information event describes the successful operation of a program, driver, or service.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,,"Warning|Error|Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",^(211|427|602|603|606|608|610|806|823|824|825|829|832|855|856)$,,skip].logeventid(211|427|602|603|606|608|610|806|823|824|825|829|832|855|856)}=1
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,,"Warning|Error|Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",^(211|427|602|603|606|608|610|806|823|824|825|829|832|855|856)$,,skip].nodata({$EVENTLOGTIME})}=1 or {TRIGGER.VALUE}=0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Database Integrity Errors Part 1
trigger_prototype.description:
Microsoft SQL Server database integrity errors from Microsoft Windows Event Viewer.
Application (program) events. The Application log contains events logged by applications or programs. Events are classified as error, warning, or information, depending on the severity of the event. An error is a significant problem, such as loss of data. A warning is an event that isn't necessarily significant, but might indicate a possible future problem. An information event describes the successful operation of a program, driver, or service.

trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,,"Warning|Error|Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",^(1509|1522|3301|3302|3624|3864|4134|5029|5180|8440|8443|8444|8461|8646|9003|9015|9100|9655|9657|17065|17066|17067)$,,skip].nodata({$EVENTLOGTIME})}=1 or {TRIGGER.VALUE}=0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Database Integrity Errors Part 2
trigger_prototype.description:
Microsoft SQL Server database integrity errors from Microsoft Windows Event Viewer.
Application (program) events. The Application log contains events logged by applications or programs. Events are classified as error, warning, or information, depending on the severity of the event. An error is a significant problem, such as loss of data. A warning is an event that isn't necessarily significant, but might indicate a possible future problem. An information event describes the successful operation of a program, driver, or service.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,"Error: 60000","Information|Warning|Error|Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",^(17061)$,,skip].logeventid(17061)}=1 and {TRIGGER.VALUE}=0
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,"Error: 60000","Information|Warning|Error|Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",^(17061)$,,skip].nodata({$EVENTLOGTIME})}=1 or {TRIGGER.VALUE}=0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Long running SQL Agent job
trigger_prototype.description: SQL Agent job has been running for more than 360 minutes.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,"Error: 60001","Information|Warning|Error|Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",^(17061)$,,skip].logeventid(17061)}=1 and {TRIGGER.VALUE}=0
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,"Error: 60001","Information|Warning|Error|Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",^(17061)$,,skip].nodata({$EVENTLOGTIME})}=1 or {TRIGGER.VALUE}=0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Not synchronized logins or jobs
trigger_prototype.description: Availability Groups replicas on server {#SQLINSTANCENAME} have not synchronized SQL server logins or SQL Agent jobs.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,,"Warning|Error|Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",^(17883|17884|17887|17888)$,,skip].logeventid(17883|17884|17887|17888)}=1
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,,"Warning|Error|Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",^(17883|17884|17887|17888)$,,skip].nodata({$EVENTLOGTIME})}=1 or {TRIGGER.VALUE}=0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: SQL Server hang condition
trigger_prototype.description: Msg 17883, 17884, 17887, or 17888 was logged in the Windows Application Event Log. These errors indicate that a hang condition was detected by SQL Server. This condition can result in application problems such as login timeouts, query timeouts, or execution failures. In some cases, this condition is isolated to a set of users based on a scheduler. In other cases the entire SQL Server might be affected. This error condition can often be the cause of a cluster failover.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,,"Information|Warning|Error|Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",^(9002)$,,skip].logeventid(9002)}=1
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:eventlog[Application,,"Information|Warning|Error|Critical","{#SQLINSTANCENAME}",^(9002)$,,skip].nodata({$EVENTLOGTIME})}=1 or {TRIGGER.VALUE}=0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME}: Transaction log for database is full
trigger_prototype.description: The transaction log for database is full. To find out why space in the log cannot be reused, see the log_reuse_wait_desc column in sys.databases. Solutions: Create a backup and truncate the transaction logs. Make the log space available. Move log file to another disk drive. Increase the size of log file. Add another log file on a separate disk.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:service.info[{#SQLINSTANCESERVICE}].last(#1)}>0 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:service.info[{#SQLINSTANCESERVICE}].last(#1)}<255 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:service.info[{#SQLINSTANCESERVICE}].last(#2)}>0 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:service.info[{#SQLINSTANCESERVICE}].last(#2)}<255 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:service.info[{#SQLINSTANCESERVICE}].last(#3)}>0 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:service.info[{#SQLINSTANCESERVICE}].last(#3)}<255
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} SQL Server: Service State {ITEM.LASTVALUE}

discovery_rule.name: SQL Server System Databases Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Microsoft SQL Server system database discovery with additional scripts lets discover Microsoft SQL Server system databases. System databases here are: master, model, msdb, tempdb. Resource database is excluded from discovery and monitoring.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#SYSDBNAME}: Full Backup Status
item_prototype.description: System database full backup status from msdb.dbo.backupset.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#SYSDBNAME}: Status
item_prototype.description: 0 = Online 1 = Restoring 2 = Recovering: SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 3 = Recovery pending : SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 4 = Suspect 5 = Emergency: SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 6 = Offline: SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 7 = Copying : Azure SQL Database Active Geo-Replication 10 = Offline Secondary : Azure SQL Database Active Geo-Replication 21 = Mirrored, Secondary Synchronized 23 = Mirrored, Principal, Synchronized 25 = Mirrored, Secondary, Not Synchronized 26 = Mirrored, Principal, Not Synchronized 31 = Always On, Synchronized 35 = Always On, Not Synchronized 40 = Log Shipping, Standby / Read-Only 41 = Log Shipping, Restoring 42 = Log Shipping, Recovering

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.sysdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME}].last(#1)}=1 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.sysdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME}].last(#2)}=1 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.sysdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME}].last(#3)}=1 or {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.sysdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME}].last(#1)}=2 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.sysdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME}].last(#2)}=2 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.sysdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME}].last(#3)}=2 or {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.sysdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME}].last(0)}>2 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.sysdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME}].last(0)}<11 or {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.sysdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME}].last(#1)}=25 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.sysdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME}].last(#2)}=25 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.sysdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME}].last(#3)}=25 or {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.sysdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME}].last(#1)}=26 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.sysdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME}].last(#2)}=26 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.sysdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME}].last(#3)}=26 or {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.sysdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME}].last(0)}=35
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#SYSDBNAME}: Status {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description: 0 = Online 1 = Restoring 2 = Recovering: SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 3 = Recovery pending : SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 4 = Suspect 5 = Emergency: SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 6 = Offline: SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 7 = Copying : Azure SQL Database Active Geo-Replication 10 = Offline Secondary : Azure SQL Database Active Geo-Replication 21 = Mirrored, Secondary Synchronized 23 = Mirrored, Principal, Synchronized 25 = Mirrored, Secondary, Not Synchronized 26 = Mirrored, Principal, Not Synchronized 31 = Always On, Synchronized 35 = Always On, Not Synchronized 40 = Log Shipping, Standby / Read-Only 41 = Log Shipping, Restoring 42 = Log Shipping, Recovering

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:backup.sysdatabasefull.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME},{$SYSDBFTIME1},{$SYSDBFTIME2},{$SYSDBFTIME3}].last(,0)}=2
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} System Database {#SYSDBNAME}: Full Backup is older then {$SYSDBFTIME1} hours
trigger_prototype.description: System database full backup is older then {$SYSDBFTIME1} hours. Status from msdb.dbo.backupset.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:backup.sysdatabasefull.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME},{$SYSDBFTIME1},{$SYSDBFTIME2},{$SYSDBFTIME3}].last(,0)}=3
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} System Database {#SYSDBNAME}: Full Backup is older then {$SYSDBFTIME2} hours
trigger_prototype.description: System database full backup is older then {$SYSDBFTIME2} hours. Status from msdb.dbo.backupset.

dependency.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} System Database {#SYSDBNAME}: Full Backup is older then {$SYSDBFTIME1} hours

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:backup.sysdatabasefull.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME},{$SYSDBFTIME1},{$SYSDBFTIME2},{$SYSDBFTIME3}].last(,0)}=4
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} System Database {#SYSDBNAME}: Full Backup is older then {$SYSDBFTIME3} hours
trigger_prototype.description: System database full backup is older then {$SYSDBFTIME3} hours. Status from msdb.dbo.backupset.

dependency.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} System Database {#SYSDBNAME}: Full Backup is older then {$SYSDBFTIME2} hours

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:backup.sysdatabasefull.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#SYSDBNAME},{$SYSDBFTIME1},{$SYSDBFTIME2},{$SYSDBFTIME3}].last(,0)}=0
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} System Database {#SYSDBNAME}: Full Backup status unavailable
trigger_prototype.description: System database backup status from msdb.dbo.backupset is unavailable.

discovery_rule.name: SQL Server Databases Discovery
discovery_rule.description: SQL Server system database discovery with additional scripts lets discover Microsoft SQL Server user databases. Distribution database is discovered as user database.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Diff Backup Status
item_prototype.description: User database differential backup status from msdb.dbo.backupset.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Full Backup Status
item_prototype.description: User database full backup status from msdb.dbo.backupset.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Log Backup Status
item_prototype.description: User database log backup status from msdb.dbo.backupset.

item_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Status
item_prototype.description: 0 = Online 1 = Restoring 2 = Recovering: SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 3 = Recovery pending : SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 4 = Suspect 5 = Emergency: SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 6 = Offline: SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 7 = Copying : Azure SQL Database Active Geo-Replication 10 = Offline Secondary : Azure SQL Database Active Geo-Replication 21 = Mirrored, Secondary Synchronized 23 = Mirrored, Principal, Synchronized 25 = Mirrored, Secondary, Not Synchronized 26 = Mirrored, Principal, Not Synchronized 31 = Always On, Synchronized 35 = Always On, Not Synchronized 40 = Log Shipping, Standby / Read-Only 41 = Log Shipping, Restoring 42 = Log Shipping, Recovering

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:backup.userdatabasediff.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME},{$UDBDTIME1},{$UDBDTIME2},{$UDBDTIME3}].last(,0)}=12 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>21 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>25 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>40 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>41 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>42
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Diff Backup is older then {$UDBDTIME1} hours
trigger_prototype.description: Database differential backup status is older then {$UDBDTIME1} hours. Status from msdb.dbo.backupset.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:backup.userdatabasediff.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME},{$UDBDTIME1},{$UDBDTIME2},{$UDBDTIME3}].last(,0)}=13 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>21 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>25 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>40 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>41 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>42
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Diff Backup is older then {$UDBDTIME2} hours

dependency.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Diff Backup is older then {$UDBDTIME1} hours
dependency.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:backup.userdatabasediff.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME},{$UDBDTIME1},{$UDBDTIME2},{$UDBDTIME3}].last(,0)}=12 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>21 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>25 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>40 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>41 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>42

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:backup.userdatabasediff.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME},{$UDBDTIME1},{$UDBDTIME2},{$UDBDTIME3}].last(,0)}=14 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>21 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>25 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>40 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>41 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>42
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Diff Backup is older then {$UDBDTIME3} hours
trigger_prototype.description: Database differential backup status is older then {$UDBDTIME3} hours. Status from msdb.dbo.backupset.

dependency.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Diff Backup is older then {$UDBDTIME2} hours
dependency.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:backup.userdatabasediff.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME},{$UDBDTIME1},{$UDBDTIME2},{$UDBDTIME3}].last(,0)}=13 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>21 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>25 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>40 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>41 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>42

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:backup.userdatabasediff.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME},{$UDBDTIME1},{$UDBDTIME2},{$UDBDTIME3}].last(,0)}=0 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>21 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>25 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>40 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>41 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>42
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Diff Backup status unavailable
trigger_prototype.description: Database differential backup status from msdb.dbo.backupset is unavailable.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:backup.userdatabasefull.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME},{$UDBFTIME1},{$UDBFTIME2},{$UDBFTIME3}].last(,0)}=7 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>21 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>25 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>40 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>41 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(,0)}<>42

trigger_prototype.description: Database full backup status is older then {$UDBFTIME1} hours. Status from msdb.dbo.backupset.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(#1)}=1 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(#2)}=1 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(#3)}=1 or {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(#1)}=2 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(#2)}=2 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(#3)}=2 or {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(0)}>2 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(0)}<11 or {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(#1)}=25 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(#2)}=25 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(#3)}=25 or {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(#1)}=26 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(#2)}=26 and {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(#3)}=26 or {Template Microsoft SQL Server DE Tier 3:tier3.userdatabase.mssql.status[{#SQLINSTANCENAME},{#DBNAME}].last(0)}=35
trigger_prototype.name: SQL Instance {#SQLINSTANCENAME} Database {#DBNAME}: Status {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description: 0 = Online 1 = Restoring 2 = Recovering: SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 3 = Recovery pending : SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 4 = Suspect 5 = Emergency: SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 6 = Offline: SQL Server 2008 through SQL Server 2017 7 = Copying : Azure SQL Database Active Geo-Replication 10 = Offline Secondary : Azure SQL Database Active Geo-Replication 21 = Mirrored, Secondary Synchronized 23 = Mirrored, Principal, Synchronized 25 = Mirrored, Secondary, Not Synchronized 26 = Mirrored, Principal, Not Synchronized 31 = Always On, Synchronized 35 = Always On, Not Synchronized 40 = Log Shipping, Standby / Read-Only 41 = Log Shipping, Restoring 42 = Log Shipping, Recovering
